keywords.term: Clifford, Peter A. Long (Clifford, Williams), Grace E. Clifford, Alice B. Burt. J. J. White, W. H. DeLang, James Hanford, C. H. Ayres, A. Reeves Matthew, H. M. Herice, Deevnay Fuller, Melville W. Hopkins, C. B. Stringer, John Heade, Matthew H. Tallman, Boyd J. Humphreys, William P. Allison, William B. Norris, George E. Huxston, R. I. Koepfli, C. A. div1.p: IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTO, IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF KING
Peter A. Clifford, Petitioner, vs Herbert O. Wiliams, and Grace E. Williams, Respondents
Exhibit A No. 41727 PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
To the Honorable George E. Morris, one of the judges of the Superior Court of the State of Washington, in and for the County of King.
The Petition of Peter A. Clifford respectfully shows:-
I.

That at all of the times herein stated he was and now is a citizen and resident of the State of California, and that defendants are and for more than three months last past have been citizens and residents of the State of Washington, in the County of King.
II.

That on the 17th, day of October, A.D.1899, one Grace E. Long was a citizen and resident of the State of California and on that day your petitioner and the said Grace E. Long, at the City and County of San Francisco, in the said State of California, intermar- ried and became husband and wife, and the said Grace E. Long thereby became Grace E. Clifford.
III.

That thereafter your petitioner and his said wife lived together as such husband and wife in the City and County of San Francisco, State of California until about the 7th day of March A. D. 1901, and that on or about the said last named day the said Grace E. Clifford deserted and abandoned your petitioner without any just cause and without his consent.
IV.

That during the marriage of your petitioner and the said Grace E. Clifford, there was born to them, as the issue of said marriage, a female child, now living, and of the age of three years and six months, named Alice B. Clifford.
V.

That on the 24th. day of March, A.D.1902, the said Grace E. Clifford commenced an action in the Superior Court in and for the City and County of San Francisco, State of California, for an absolute divorce from your petitioner, and therein prayed for the custody of said child of said marriage, and your petitioner appeared in said action and filed his answer, and also a cross-complaint for a divorce from the said Grace E. Clifford therein, and in said cross-complaint orayed that the custody of said child should be awarded to him by said Court.
VI.

That thereafter such proceedings were had in such action and cross-action that the judgment of said Court was given, made and entered therein, denying a divorce to said Grace E. Clifford and granting a divorce to your petitioner, and awarding the custody of said child to Grace E. Clifford until further order of the Court; and providing that your petitioner should be allowed to see said child once a week and to take the same out with him once in every two weeks.
VII.

That at the time of the commencement of said action and from thence on down and including the time of the entry of said judgment, your petitioner, the said Grace E. Clifford and said child were all citizens and bona fide residents of said City and County of San Fran- cisco, in said State of California, and actually present therein, and your petitioner and the said Grace E. Clifford had been such citizens and residents of said City and County continuously since the date of their said marriage, and said child had been such citizen and resident continuously since the date of her birth, and within the jurisdiction of said Superior Court was then and yet is a Court of record and of superior jurisdiciton.
VIII.

That aftet the date of entry of said judgment by said Superior Court, the said Grace E. Clifford continued to reside in said City and County of San Fransisco until sometime in September, A.D.1903, the exact time being unknown to your petitioner, and that during said month she secretly and surreptitiously and without the permission of said Superior Court, and in contempt thereof, and with- out the knowledge or consent of your petitioner, took said child out of the State of California.
IX.

That on the 27th day of November, A.D. 1903, you petitioner filed in the Superior Court a verified petition on said action and cross-action for a modification of the judgment therein by taking away from the custody of said Grace E. Clifford the said child and awarding the custody thereof to your petitioner, and such proceedings were thereupon made had that an order was made and entered therein modifying and changing said judgment and taking the custody of said child from said Grace E. Clifford and awarding the same to your petitioner until the further order of the said Superior Court, and said order ever since has been and still is standing and not set aside and in full force and effect, and under the laws of the State of California, at the time of the commencement of said action and at the time of the entry of said judgment, and at the time of the making of said order, said child was a ward of said Court and under the control thereof; and it is provided by the laws of the said State that said Court could be at any time after the entry of said judg- ment make any order with or without notice modifying said judgment as to make the custody of said child.
X.

That since the judgment of divorce, the said Grace E. Clifford and one Herbert O. Williams above named, intermarried in said State of California, and became and ever since have been and now are husband and wife, and ever since their said marriage have had in the State of California and elsewhere and now have at the town of Georgetown in said County of King, said child in their custody and possession.
XI.

That on the 19th, day of January, 1904 at the said town of Georgetown, your petitioner presented to the said Herbert O. O. Williams and the said Grace E. Williams a copy of the record and proceedings of the said Superior Court of said City and County of San Francisco, in said action and cross-action, certified under and in pursuance of an act of the Congress of the United States, in such case made and provided and demanded from them and each of them immediate delivery of said child to him, said petitioner, but they refused and still do refuse to give up said child, and said child ever since has been and now is imprisoned and restrained of her liberty by them at said town of Georgetown, and that according to the best of your petitioner's knowledge and belief, the cause or pre- tense of the aforesaid confinement or restraint of the said Alice B. Clifford is that under the said judgment of said Superior Court of said City and County of San Francisco, the custody of said child was given to the said Grace E. Clifford now Grace E. Williams. until futher order of that Court, and that after she, secretly and surreptituously took said child beyond the limits of said State of California, as aforesaid, said Superior Court lost all jurisdiction to make any further order in said action or cross-action, in regard to, in modification of said judgment, as to the custody of said child, and that after said child was brought into the said State of Washing- ton, said Herbert O. Williams, with the consent of said Grace E. Williams, and without the knowledge or consent of said Superior Court of said City and County of San Francisco, undertook, under the laws of the said State of Washington, to adopt said child as his own. And your petitioner further states that he is advised by counsel W. H. White, Esq., resding at the City of Seattle, State of Washington, and J. J. Burt, Esq., residing at the City and County of San Francisco, State of California, that the said imprisonment of the said child, Alice B. Clifford, is illegal and that the illegality consists in this, towit:-

That said Superior Court of the said City and County of San Francisco had jurisdiction to award the custody of said child, upon the facts herein before alleged, until further order of the Court, and to thereafter change or modify thhe judgment as to the custody of saaid child, with or without notice to any or either of the parties to said action, and that under Article 4, Section I, of the Constitution of the United States, full faith and credit must be given in the State of Washingto to the acts and proceedings of said Superior Court of the City and County of San Francisco, and all persons and Courts must recognize the petitioner's right to the custody of said child under said order, in said State of Washington, as well as under the laws of the country existing between said State of California and said State of Washington. And your petitioner further states that there is danger that the said Herbert O. Williams and the ssaid Grace E. Williams will take or send the said child out of this State, from the fact that they secretly and without the per- mission of the said Superior Court of the City and County of San Francisco and in contempt thereof, took said child beyond the limits of the State of California.

WHEREFORE, your Petitioner prays a writ of habeas corpus to bring up the body of said child, Alice B. Clifford, to abide such order as your Honor may direct, and that also a warrant issue immedi- ately to take said child.
(sgd.) Peter A. Clifford
(sgd.) W. H. White. Attorney for Peitioner.
(sgd.) J. J. Burt, of, Counsel.

Peter A. Clifford, being duly sworn, says: That he is the Petitioner above named; that he has read the foregoing, his petition, and knows the contents thereof, and that the same is, and that the facts therein stated are true of his ow knowledge.
(sgd.) Peter A. Clifford.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 19th day of January, A.D. 1904.
(sgd.) R. I. Huxston. A Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
Ex. A Con

Upon the reading and filing of the foregoing Petition verified by the Petitioner, whereby it appears that Alice B. Clifford is illegally imprisoned and restrained of her liberty by Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, at the town of Georgetown, in the County of King, State of Washington, and stating wherein the illegality consists, from which is appears to me that a writ of habeas corpus should issue :+

It is ordered that a writ of habeas corpus issue out of and under the deal of the Superior Court of the State of Washington, in and for the County of King, directed to the said Herbert O. William and Grace E. Williams, commanding them and each of them to have the body of Alice B. Clifford before me May 33, 1904 at 1:30 of such day in the Court room of said Court to do and receive what shall then and there be considered concerning the said Alice B. Clifford, to- gether with the time and cause of her detention, and that they have then and there the said writ.

It further appearing that there is good reason to believe that said Alice B. Clifford, will be carried out of and beyond the juris- diction of said Court, it ordered that a warrant issue out of and under the seal of said Court to the Sheriff of King County, com- manding him to take the said Alice B. Clifford and to hold her in custody until the determination of said Petition.
Dated, January 20, 1904.
(sgd.) Geo. E. Morris, Judge.
"Exhibit B"
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OFmWASHINGTON, FOR KING COUNTY.
Peter A. Clifford, Petitioner, vs. Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, Respondents.
No. Writ of Habeas Corpus.
The people of the state of Washington, to Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, Greeting.

We command you that you have the body of Alice B. Clifford now held by you in illegal custody and detention, by whatsoever name the said Alice B. Clifford shall be called, before the Hon. George E. Mor- ris, one of the judges of the above named court, at the court room of said court and department three thereof, in the City of Seattle, Count of King, State of Washington, on the 22nd day of January, 1904, at 1:30 o'clock P. M. of said day, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered and determined concerning the said Alice B. Clif- ford, and that you have then and there this writ.
Witness the Hon. Geoorge E. Morris, one of the judges of the Superior Court of the state of Washington, in and for the County of King.
C. A. Koepli, (Signed.) Clerk.
(Seal.) by J. M. Brewster, Deputy.
Exhibit "C"
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, FOR KING COUNTY.
Peter A. Clifford, Petitioner, vs. Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, his wife, Respondents.
No. 41727. Answer.
Come now the respondents herein by their attorneys Sweeney and Steiner, and answer the petitioner's petition as follows:
I.
Respondents admit the allegations of the first paragraph of said petition.
II.
Respondents admit the allegations of the second paragraph of said petition.
III.

Answering the third paragraph of said petition, respondents admit that respondent Grace E. Williams and petitioner lived together as husband and wife in the city and county of San Francisco until about the 7th day of March, 1901, and deny each and every other alle- gation in said paragraph.
IV.
Respondents admit the allegations of the fourth paragraph of said petition.
V.
Respondents admit the allegations of the fifth paragraph of said petition.
VI.
Answering paragraph six of said petition, respondents admit that the care, custody and control of the child Alice B. Clifford was awarded to the respondent Grace E. Williams, then Grace E. Clifford.
VII.
Respondents admit the allegations of paragraph seven of said petition.
VIII.

Answering paragraph eight of said petition, respondents admit that they left the state of California and came to King County, Wash- ington, but deny that the departure was secretly, surreptitiously, or without the permission of the Superior Court of the County of San Francisco.
IX.

Answering paragraph nine of said petition, respondents have no information sufficient to form a belief as to the truth or falsity of the allegations therein contained, and therefore deny the same, and and further allege that at the time said decree is alleged to havecbeen amended respondent Grace E. Williams and Alice B. Clifford (now Alice B. Williams) were not redients of nor in the State of California but were residents of King County, Washington. That no notice whatever was served upon respondents or either of them now did they or either of them receive any information concerning an attempted change of the decree awarding said child to respondent, Grace E. Williams.
X.
Respondents admit the allegations of paragraph 10 of said petition.
XI.

Answering paragraph eleven of said petition, respondents admit that they refused to deliver said child to petitioner, and denynthe allegations concerning which respondents have knowledge; and respondents have no information sufficient to form a belief as to the truth or falsity of the remaining allegations, and therefore deny the same.
For a separate and affirmative defense to petitioner's petition, respondents allege:
I.

That respondent, Grace E. Williams, then Grace. E. Long, and petitioner, Peter A. Clifford, then residents of San Francisco, Cali- fornia, were married in San Francisco, California, on or about the 17th, day of October, 1899; that very soon after said marriage, petitioner came home in a state of hopeless intoxication; that at frequent inter- vals thereafter, petitioner came home drunk, at which times he was abusive to respondent, and caused her great pain and distress, so that it became impossible to longer endure his conduct, whereupon on or about July, 1900, said respondent left petitioner, and returned to her mother's home. That on or about the 5th day of August, 1900, after repeated promises on the part of petitioner to resume the duties and obligations of a husband toward said respondent, said respondent returned to petitioner with a view to living with him again as his wife. That very soon thereafter, petitioner became abusive, commenced drinking and neglecting said respondent, and failed to provide for her comfort, and respondent, who was then an expectant mother, ws sore distressed; that their child, Alice B. Clifford, was born on October 14, 1900; that thereafter petitioner refused to provide for respondent's comfort, or to provide her with medical attendance and neglected her so that on or about the day of March, 1901, said respondent was compelled to and did leave said petitioner and returned again to hermother's home, where she was provided with medical attendance and other comforts necessary to herself and child, That during the time petitioner and said respondent lived together, petitioner wholly failed to provide her with clothing which during all of said time was furnished her by her mother. That in April, 1902, said respondent brought an action for divorce from petitioner which resulted in a decree of the Superior Court of San Francisco County, California, dissolving the bonds of matrimony theretofore existing between said respondent and petitioner and awarding the sole care of custody and control of their infant child, Alice B. Clifford, to said respondent, its mother, a copy of which said decree is hereto attached marked "Exhibit A" and is hereby referred to and made a part of this answer.

That thereafterm in or about the 15th, day of August, 1903, said respondent and Herbert O. Williams were intermarried in San Fran- cisco, California, and ever since have been and now are husband and wife. That on or about the 24th, day of September, 1903, respondents left the State of California and came to Seattle, King County, Washington, to make iit possible for Herbert O. Williams to enter to employ of his brother, Charles L. Williams, who was then and is now a prominent contractor and builder in the City of Seattle. That since coming to Seattle, said Herbert O. Williams has been in his brother's employ as a carpenter and has been earning and does now earn the sun of three dollars ($3.00) per day.

That thereafter, said respondents became desirous of adopting said Alice B. Clifford as their ow child, and thereupon on or about the 12th day of November, 1903, respondents petitioned the Superior Court of King County, Washington, in cause Number 5262, entitled "In the matter of the adoption of Alice B. Clifford, and infant, by Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, his wife, "for permission to adopt said child, Alice B. Clifford, as their own. That thereafter, such proceedings were had the a decree of adoption was entered bu said Superior Court of King County, Washington, adjudging that from and after said date, said infant, Alice B. Clifford should to all legal in- tents and purposes be the child of the petitioners, respondents herein, Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, the same as if she had been born to them in lawful wedlock, and that the name of said child be changed to Alice B. Williams, a copy of which decree is hereto at- tached and marked "exhibit B", which is hereby referred to and made a part of this answer by virtue of which, said respondents claim the rightful posession of said infant, Alice B. Wiliams.
Respondents further allege that they are amply able to provide a suitable home for said child and to make reasonable provision for its future usefulness and happiness in life.

That respondents left the State of California not for the purpose of evading the order of nor in contempt of any Court nor did they leave secretly nor surreptitiously, but they came to the State of Washington in good faith in view of better business opportunities as aforesaid in Seattle and for the purpose of becoming bona fide citizens of the State of Washington. That respondents now are and expect to remain citizens of the State of Washington.

WHEREFORE, respondents pray that the writ of habeas corpus issued herein may be dissolved, and that said child, Alice B. Williams, be released from the custody of the Sheriff of King County, and returned to the custody and keeping of respondents, Grace E. Williams and Herbert O. Williams, and for their costs and disbursements n this behalf expended.
(sgd.) Sweeney and Steiner Atttys. for Resp.

Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, being first duly sworn, on oath depose and say: That they are the respondents above named; that they have read the foregoing answer, know the contents thereof, and the statements therein made are true.
(sgd.) H. O. Williams. (sgd.) Grace E. Williams.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 22nd, day of January, 1904.
(sgd.) G. E. Steiner. Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
"Exhibit D"
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, FOR KING COUNTY.
Peter A. Clifford, Petitioner, vs. Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, his wife, Respondents.
No.
O R D E R .

Whereas, a writ of habeas corpus was on the 20th, day of January, 1904, issued herein upon the petition of Peter A. Clifford, in behalf of Alice B. Williams, designated in said petition as Alice B. Clifford, directed to Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, respondents herein, and

Whereas, on the 22nd, day of January, 1904, the said Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, in obedience to said writ of habeas corpus, produced the body of said Alice B. Williams before this Court, and made answer and return to said petition, and

Whereas, a hearing on said petition and return was continued on the 25th day of January, 1904, at which time petitioner appeared in person and by his attorneys, W. H. White and Bert, and respondets appeared in person and by their attorneys, Sweeney and Steiner, and evidence having been introduced and argument of counsel heard, and the Court being fully advised in the premises, finds as follows:-
I. That on the 17th, day of October, 1899, respondent Grace E. Williams, then Grace E. Long, and petitioner Peter A. Clifford, in- termarried in San Francisco, California.

2. That to said Peter A. Clifford and his then wife, Grace E. Clifford, a female child was born on the 14th. day of October, 190, which child is now living, named Alice B. Clifford, the same being the child in controversey in this cause.

3. that on the 20th, day of May, 1902, a decree was entered in the Superior Court of the State of California, in and for the City and County of San Francisco, in cause numbered 30,124, entitled, "Grace E. Clifford, plaintiff, vs. Peter A. Clifford, Defendant", dissolving the bonds of matrimony then and theretofore existing between said Grace E. Clifford and Peter A. Clifford, and awarding the sole charge, con- trol and custody of said Alice B. Clifford to respondent, Grace E. Williams.

4. That subsequent to said divorce, and on or about August 15, 1903, respondents, Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, then Grace E. Clifford, intermarried in the State of California, and thereafter on or about the 20th day of September, 1903, said respon- dents together with said infant, Alice B. Clifford, removed from the State of California to the State of Washington, and thereupon became bone fide residents of King County, Washington.

5. That said Alice B. Williams, then Alice B. Clifford, was in the care, custody and control of respondent, Grace E. Williams at the time of her marriage with said Herbert O. Williams, and was brought with said respondents to King County, Washington, and has since been in the custody of resided with said respondets.

That on or about the 12h day of November, 190, respondents, Herbert O. Williams, petitioned the Superior Court of King County, Washington, in the cause numbered 5262, entitled "In the matter of the adoption of Alice B. Clifford, an infant, by Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, his wife," for permission to adopt said child under the laws of the State of Washington.

7. That thereupon such proceedings were had that a decree was entered in said causem adjudging from and after said date said child, Alice B. Clifford should to all legal intents and purposes be the child of petitioners in said suit, Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams his wife, the same as if the child had been born to them in lawful wedlock, and that the name of said child be changed to Alice B. Williams.

8. That subsequent to said adoption, and on the 15th, day of December, 1903, the petitioner applied to the Superior Court of the State of California in and for the City of San Francisco, for an order amending the decree granted in the aforesaid divorce proceeding, and awarding the custody of the said infant Alice B. Clifford to petitioner, which order was then and there granted; that respondents had no notice of the application for said order, and were at that time, together with said infant, residents of King County, Washington.

9. That the Superior Court of King County, Washington, had jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter in the adop- tion proceedings mentioned in paragrapg six of these findings, and that said proceedings were in every respect regular and in accord- ance with the statutes of the state of Washington.

The court further finds that the respondents Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Wiliams are fit and proper persons to have the care, custody and control of said infant Alice B. Williams, and the best interests of said infant require that she remain in the care, cus- today and control of said respondents.

It is therefore ORDERED, tha the said infant Alice B. Williams be and she is hereby remanded to the care, custody and control of respondents Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams; that they retain the care, custody and control of said infant; that the writ of habeas corpus heretofore issued herein be dissolved, and that respondents recover from petitioner their costs in this behalf ex- pended.

It is further ordered that the bond heretofore given in this cause be cancelled, and the bondsman released from all liability, and that the cash bond, if any, in the hands of the sheriff of King County be returned to said bondsmen.
Done in open court this 29th day of January, 1904.
(Signed) Boyd J. Tallman, Judge.
Exhibit E.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, FOR KING COUNTY.
In the matter of the adoption of Alice B. Clifford, an infant, by Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams, his wife.
No. Decree.

That cause coming on for hearing this 12th day of November, 1903, the petitioners appearing in person and by their at- torneys Sweeney, French, and Steiner, the petitioners being accompanied by said infant Alice B. Clifford, and evidence having been adduced and witnesses examined, and the court being fully advised in the premises finds as follows:
1. That petitioners Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams are Husband and wife and are residents of Seattle, King County, Washington.

2. That Alice B. Clifford is three years of age; that her parents, Peter A. Clifford and his then wife Grace E. Clifford were divorced by decree of the Superior Court of San Francisco County, california, on or about May 20, 1902; that said decree by its terms, awarded the care,, custody and control of said infant Alice B. Clifford, to its mother Grace E. Clifford, now Grace E. Williams; that said Alice B. Clifford is three years of age, and is a resident of Seattle, King County, Washington.

3. That said Peter A. Clifford and his then wife Grace E. Clifford, have, ever since the granting of said divorce and for a long time pri- or thereto, lived separate and apart, during all of which time said infant Alice B. Clifford has been and now is in the care, custody and control of its mother.

4. That the petitioners are persons of good moral character, indus- trious habits, of good prospects in life, of the age of 31 years and 22 years respectively, are amply able to provide a suitable home for said infantchild and are in every respect able to bring up said child and furnish suitable nurture and education therefor and that it is fit and proper that such adoption should be made.

WHEREFORE, It is ordered, adjuged and decreed, in accordance with the statutes in such case made and providedm that from this date the said child Alice B. Clifford shall to all legal inetends and pur- poses be the child of petitioners Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams his wife, and for purposes of inheritance and all other legal incidents and consequences, shall be the same as if she had been borne to them in lawful wedlock, and that the name of said Alice B. Clifford be and the same is hereby changed to Alice B. Williams, according to the prayer of the petitioners herein.
Done in open court this 12th day of November, 1903.
(Signed.) Boyd J. Tallman. Judge.
Tx
CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
Peter A. Clifford, Petitioner, vs. Herbert O. Williams and Grace E. Williams. Respondents.
Answer. Sweeney and Steiner, Attorney for Respondents.
FILED IN THE U. S. Circuit Court, DIST. OF WASHINGTON, JUN 20 1904 A. REEVES AYRES, Clerk HM Matthew Deputy
